() , ? asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order : (a) Will he inform this House, (i) whether a plot of land nearly 40 acres in extent, situated in Katupaththewa of Katupaththewa Grama Niladhari Division in Nochchiyagama Divisional Secretarys Division in the Anuradhapura District, has been leased to a non-government a organization or an individual ; (ii) if it has been leased or sold, the name of the institute concerned and when it was done ; and, (iii) for what purpose it has been given ?

(b) Is he aware that the institute which acquired this land get water by impounding a tributary of Kala Oya ? (c) Will he state, (i) whether legal permission has been obtained to impound the tributary of Kala Oya ; (ii) If so, from which institution ? (d) Will he admit that due to obtaining water in this way, farmers engaged in cultivating around the tributary in Katupaththewa area are faced with problems in obtaining water ? (e) Will he take steps to provide speedy relief to the farmers inconvenienced due to this project ? (f) If not why ?

() , ? asked the Minister of National Heritage : (a) will he inform this House,- (i) the number of vehicles obtained for the Minister of National Heritage and his personal staff; (ii) the basis on which these vehicles have been obtained; (iii) out of them, the number of vehicles obtained on hire or contract basis? (b) Will he state in this House from which institutions or individuals the said vehicles have been obtained, along with their names and addresses? (c) will he state separately in respect of each vehicle,- (i) the types of such vehicles;
(ii) the amount of money spent on those vehicles and the amount of money allocated for fuel, monthly and annually? (d) Will he state,-
(i) if drivers had been recruited for these vehicles, the basis on which they were recruited;
(ii) their salaries and allowances? (e) If not, why?

( . . . ) (The Hon. R. P. A. Ranaweera Pathirana) - (1) : () (i) , 2006 2007 ; (ii) , ; ?

asked the Minister of Transport : (a) Will he state in this House, (i) whether scrap metal belonging to the Department of Railways was sold in the years 2006 and 2007 ; (ii) if so, the amount sold from each metal in the respective years ? (b) Will he inform this House, (i) whether the tender procedure was followed when metal was sold in the years 2005 and 2006 ; (ii) the number of bidders, if tenders were so called ; (iii) the policy followed in awarding tenders ? (c) Will he submit to this House separately, the price at which each type to metal was sold ? (d) Will he admit that even usable carriages belonging to the Department of Railways had been sold when these metals were sold ? (e) Will he state, (i) whether a fraud or an act of corruption had taken place in selling the scrap metal ; (ii) if so, the action taken against them ? (F) If not, why ?

Question ordered to stand down. : : HIS EXCELLENCY THE PRESIDENTS VISIT TO CHINA : DETAILS 1102/07 9.

asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration, and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order : (a) will he inform this House with regard to His Excellency the Presidents visit to China from end February to first week of March, 2007,

(i) all the agreements signed between Sri Lanka and China; (ii) if not so, the agreements or letters of intent; (iii) the benefits received accordingly as of today; (iv) the direct benefits accrued from this visit? (b) Will he state in detail,

() , ? asked the Minister of Higher Education : (a) will she inform this House whether,- (i) permission was granted to Aquinas Institution to start a university, at the 696th meeting of the University Grants Commission held on 12th December, 2004; and, (ii) this has been further legalized through a Gazette Notification in October 2005? (b) Is he aware that the Lankadeepa newspaper on 23rd July, 2006 carried a news item on page 16 that Aquinas private University would be restarted? (c) Will he inform this House.- (i) whether steps were taken to prevent this; (ii) If so, what they are; (iii) what actions were taken thereafter since it was mentioned again in the Lankadeepa newspaper on 15th October, 2006 on page 19 that the Aquinas Institution would be started? (d) Will he state.- (i) the reply given to about 12,000 students of the Inter University Students Federation when they launched a protest March on 30th November, 2006 demanding that this be prevented; (ii) whether it was agreed to suspened the functioning of the Aquinas Instituion before 31st December, at the meeting which the Inter University Students Federation has with the then Minister concerned on 8th December? (e) Will he admit that there were references in newspapers on 11th February again to the effect that students would be enrolled to the the Aquinas Institution? (f) Will he state in this House, the legal actions taken in regard to the above instances? (g) If not, why?

( ) (The Hon. Kabir Hashi . 260 ? . 260 . - - . . . , . Sir, I would like to switch onto English because I have a very short time left. There are seven areas which cause inflation. Though I said seven, it is actually five. One is, high budget deficit. The other is, how you finance this budget deficit. The third is the excess money supply that

results after a high budget deficit. The fourth is the creation of inflation itself which again results in higher interest rates and the depreciation of the currency and finally the result of all this would be hyperinflation. This country has all these symptoms. We have a high budget deficit. Why is there a high budget deficit? It is not because of the reasons these Ministers give; it is not because of expenditure on the war but because there are 110 Ministers who have to be looked after and fed. It is not easy to feed these 110 Ministers. Then there are unlimited amounts of foreign trips for these Ministers, the President and his entourage. Millions of rupees are spent on them. Then, there is a huge amount of capital expenditure which goes unchecked, which is not for productive purposes. For example, Mihin Air has no productive use for this country. We have already the SriLankan Airlines which could be developed. Mihin Air is eating into the reserves of this country. Millions of rupees has been spent for the development of Mihin Air. Instead of setting up Mihin Air, we should have developed a railway line. We should have developed the railway system because ordinary people have to travel; they cannot ever fly by Mihin Air. Due to this wasteful expenditure, the budget deficit has increased by huge figures in the last two years. If you take the financing of the budget deficit, how have they financed it? They have printed money. In the last two years huge amounts of money have been printed. In 2006 something like Rs. 40 billion was printed. Then, Treasury bonds have been put into the market. The Central Bank has started issuing Treasury bonds to raise more money. There have been huge amounts of dollar borrowings. Dollar Bonds have been issued in order to bridge the budget deficit. If you look at all these situations, the result has been higher interest rates in the country and today you cannot borrow at less than 22 per cent due to the depreciation of our currency. There is something called the theory of purchasing power parity. That is, the exchange rate of a country is determined by the relative inflationary levels of that country and its trading partners. So, if you look at the inflation within Sri Lanka and inflation in the regional countries with whom we trade, in those countries inflation is low and in our country inflation is high. As a result to off set our inflation, we have to depreciate our currency. What has resulted is the crashing of the rupee. As a result of the rupee crashing, the prices of all the imported essential commodities have gone sky high.

What I am trying to tell this House and the people of the country is that the cost of living has gone up not because of the price of oil. The cost of living has gone up because of economic mismanagement, robbery, theft and wastage. To confirm this is, I will give you the figures. If you look at a few other countries in comparison, in the year 2007, currently -

( ) (The Hon. Kabir Hashim) . In the United States, the inflationary rate is only 2.7 per cent. In Japan it is almost nil. In China it is only 4.4 per cent. If you take Turkey, a country which is not managed well, it is 8.6 per cent. India is a regional country and it is only 6.6 per cent. If you take Malaysia, it is only 1.4 per cent. In Pakistan it is only 7 per cent. If you take Thailand, it is only 1.9 per cent. If you take even Venezuela, a country which is producing oil, the inflation is 19 per cent because Venezuela is also a country that is mismanaged. Now, Sri Lanka has an inflationary rate of 20 per cent. So, what I am trying to say is, if other countries can have low inflationary rates with prices coming down even though oil prices are high in those countries, why is it that only in Sri Lanka, prices are going up? That is because of the wastage and the amount of theft that is going on within this country. Since there is limited time, I would like to conclude saying that it is the responsibility of the Government to ensure that the cost of living is controlled and not to make excuses about the war; not to make excuse about oil prices, because that cannot be accepted. Thank you.
